holdings.text: The surplus derived by the assessee in the sale of its shares and securities in the relevant previous years was a revenue receipt and as such taxable under the Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question that has come up for consideration is -- Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the surplus derived by the assessee in the sale of its shares and securities in the relevant previous years was a revenue receipt and as such taxable under the Income Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show shares purchased in falling market with borrowed funds for profit, not dividend income; sold at profit; explanation of loss of control unproved; subsequent trading activity confirms trading intent.

holdings.text: The sale of these shares by the assessee resulted in a revenue receipt, not a capital gain.

anchor.surface_text: These are the principal facts on the basis of which it has to be determined whether the sale of these shares by the assessee resulted in a revenue receipt or in a capital gain. It appears to us that the facts and circumstances in this case can lead to

holdings.reasoning_summary: Motive was earning profit from purchases and sales, not investment for dividends; MoA permits dealing; purchases in falling market with loans indicate trading.

holdings.text: These shares were purchased and sold by the assessee with the motive of earning a profit by such purchases and sales and not with the object of investing its capital in these shares in order to derive income from that investment.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the facts and circumstances in this case can lead to. no other conclusion, except that these shares were purchased and sold by the assessee with the motive of earning a profit by such purchases and sales and not with the object of investing its capital in these shares in order to derive income from that investment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts including purchase timing, market conditions, borrowings, low yield, and sale profit compel this conclusion over investment intent.

holdings.text: A decision given in earlier years is not binding in the proceedings for assessment during subsequent years.

anchor.surface_text: In the years prior to the assessment year, the case put forward by the assessee that the various acquisitions and sales of shares were in the nature of investments was accepted by The Department but such a decision given in the earlier years is not binding in the proceedings for assessment during subsequent years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects res judicata application to prior tax assessments; each year independent.

holdings.text: The purchases and sales of these shares were an adventure in the nature of trade.

anchor.surface_text: the purchases and sales of these shares were an adventure in the nature of trade. Even the sequence of events does not bear out the contention of the assessee. Sri C.L. Kanoria first resigned on 17th March, 1952 and he sold his shares while his resignation was still pending for approval by the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unproved investment/control explanation; sequence of resignation and sale; market conditions; subsequent purchases in rising market confirm trading.

holdings.text: The explanation that shares were held as investment and sold due to loss of control has not been proved.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation sought to be given by the assessee that the shares were, in fact, being held as investment and were sold simply because the control of McLeod Co. Ltd. went out of the hands of the Directors of the assessee has not been proved, according to the supplementary statement of the case submitted by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding; no material purchasers acquired control; Kanoria group retained majority post-sale.

holdings.text: The assessee dealt with the shares as stock-in-trade, even though not shown as such in account books.

anchor.surface_text: assessed under section 10, the assessee, be it an individual or a company or any other entity, must carry on business in respect of shares that is to say, the assessee must deal in those shares. It is evident that if an individual person invests in shares for the purpose of earning dividend, he is not carrying on a business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show initial purchase for resale profit; treated as trading despite bookkeeping; distinguishes mere variation from dealing.

holdings.text: Even the initial purchase of these shares by the assessee was not for the purpose of investment for earning income from dividends, but was with a view to earn profit by resale of those shares.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Ram Narain principle but finds facts show trading intent from outset, not later variation.

precedents.citation: Bengal and Assam Investors Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Bengal and Assam Investors Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 1 , which were quoted in the remand order and are as follows -- It seems to us that, on principle before dividends on shares can be assessed under section 10, the assessee, be it an individual or a company or any other entity, must carry on business in respect of shares that is to say, the assessee must deal in those shares.

precedents.case_name: Bengal and Assam Investors Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Before profits or dividends on shares can be assessed as business income under section 10 of the Income Tax Act, the assessee must carry on business in respect of shares by dealing in them; mere investment for earning dividends does not constitute business.
precedents.cited_holding: It seems to us that, on principle before dividends on shares can be assessed under section 10, the assessee... must deal in those shares. It is evident that if an individual person invests in shares for the purpose of earning dividend, he is not carrying on a business. The only way he can come under section 10 is by converting the shares into stock-in-trade

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka 2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka 2 . It was urged that, in this case, the Tribunal has recorded no finding at all that the shares in McLeod Co. Ltd. which were sold by the assessee were converted by it into stock-in-trade, no has it been held that the variation of its investments by the assessee amounted to dealings in investments.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v Bai Shirinbai K Kooka
precedents.cited_proposition: Example of an assessee carrying on the business of dealing in stocks and shares by converting shares into stock-in-trade.
precedents.cited_holding: as did the assessee in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka

precedents.citation: Ram Narain Sons Pr. Ltd. v Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain Sons Pr. Ltd. v Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1 to urge that the principal consideration in determining whether income from sale of shares is revenue income or capital gain, is to find out what was the purpose of purchase of those shares

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain Sons Pvt Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: The principal consideration in determining whether income from sale of shares is revenue or capital gain is the purpose of purchase; if for investment, profit on sale is capital gain not revenue.
